Article.ArticleTitle: Kinetic modelling assisted balancing of organic pollutant removal and bromate formation during peroxone treatment of bromide-containing waters.

AbstractText: The peroxone process (O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) is reported to be a more effective process than the ozonation process due to an increased rate of generation of hydroxyl radicals (<sup>•</sup>OH) and inhibition of bromate (BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) formation which is otherwise formed on ozonation of bromide containing waters. However, the trade-off between the H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> dosage required for minimization of BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> formation and effective pollutant removal has not been clearly delineated. In this study, employing experimental investigations as well as chemical modelling, we show that the concentration of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> required to achieve maximum pollutant removal may not be the same as that required for minimization of BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> formation. At the H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> dosage required to minimize BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> formation (<10 µg/L), only pollutants with high to moderate reactivity towards O<sub>3</sub> and <sup>•</sup>OH are effectively removed. For pollutants with low reactivity towards O<sub>3</sub>/<sup>•</sup>OH, high O<sub>3</sub> (O<sub>3</sub>:DOC>>1 g/g) and high H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> dosages (O<sub>3</sub>:H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> ∼1 (g/g)) are required for minimizing BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> formation along with effective pollutant removal which may result in a very high residual of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> in the effluent, causing secondary pollution. On balance, we conclude that the peroxone process is not effective for the removal of low reactivity micropollutants if minimization of BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> formation is also required.
